passage_text: Valuation Allowance. A contra-or reduction account to deferred tax assets. The valuation allowance represents that portion of total deferred tax assets that the firm judges is unlikely to be realized. The probability threshold applied in evaluating realization is 50%.

The valuation account term is a less-used phrase that has the same meaning as the contra account concept. Examples of valuation accounts are: 1  Allowance for doubtful accounts (paired with the trade accounts receivable account). 2  Allowance for obsolete inventory (paired with the inventory account). 3  Accumulated depreciation (paired with the various fixed asset accounts).

Valuation Allowance. Definition of Valuation Allowance Valuation AllowanceA contra-or reduction account to deferred tax assets. The valuation allowance represents that portion of total deferred tax assets that the firm judges is unlikely to be realized. The probability threshold applied in evaluating realization is 50%.

TOP CONTRIBUTORS. Parker Conrad. A valuation allowance is a balance sheet line item that offsets all or a portion of the value of a company's deferred tax assets because the company doesn't expect it will be able to realize this value. Sometimes, a company expects it will not be able to realize the benefits of its deferred tax assets.
